Mmm...

'Today is the day when it all begins, let's do this'

Mmm...

I'm a 28 year old Lithuanian living in beautiful Oslo, Norway. Although I have a degree in International Management and Marketing, I'm at my happiest in the kitchen. Currently I'm working in the organic cafe and helping to produce natural, unprocessed and clean foods.  I love to cook. I love to think about food.  And I love to eat.
People who love to eat are always the best people. ~ Julia Child
I like experimenting in the kitchen. The internet is filled with amazing, inspiring and motivating food blogs. I wish the day had more than 24 hours and I had more time to try out all the yummy recipes and give them my personal touch. Most of the time I avoid gluten, dairy and sugar and have been trying out raw recipes and 'super foods' in my diet. I like eating food that makes me feel good.
We all eat & it would be a sad waste of opportunity to eat badly. ~ Anna Thomas
I decided to start my own blog for two reasons. Firstly, for myself, to help keep track of my recipes, ideas and inspirations.  Secondly, to motivate and inspire others to make healthier choices in their every day foods and to feel healthier and HAPPIER. Because I believe that the most important thing in life is to be happy! Happiness is a choice and I choose to be Incurably Happy! Asta.

People who love to eat are always the best people. 
Julia Child

Today I woke up to a beautiful morning, sunny, blue skies, and I said to myself: 'Today is the day when it all begins again, let's run'. I put on my asics, turned on my iPod, set the Garmin watch and I was ready. Ready to run. And I went to the park and ran 5k. My body was fighting me and telling: 'just stop, it's cold, it hurts, I can't do it'. But I chose to listen to my happy and positive side: 'it's only 5k, you don't have to run fast, just take your time and you'll be fine. Think about all the joy and feeling of accomplishment afterwards'. And I ran my 5k and I didn't stop. Hurra! Let me tell you, running is not my thing, not yet. I love going to the gym, cycling, hiking and other active ways of spending time. But running is tough for me. I don't enjoy it, yet. But last year I started to run. My boyfriend Lucas is addicted to running and I was always curious why he likes running so much. So last year I signed myself for Oslo marathon to run 10k. I needed some motivation to start running. So I set myself a goal to run 10k under 1 hour. It's not very big accomplishment for most of the people. But I have never ran 10k in my life! So for me it was a big deal. Long story short, after spending my summer running and preparing, I managed to run 10k in 48:44! I was super proud and happy. This year I set myself another goal. To run half marathon. I am not sure if I can do it, since I never ran more than 10k, but we'll see what happens. I wanted to say it out load, so I won't have an excuse to quit. My preparations started today with 5k. I didn't run since last september, so I took it slow. And to tell you the truth,I don't think I could have ran more. It was tough. But it's better than nothing. I still have lots of time till Oslo marathon in september, right? I will keep you updated how it goes. One thing what I really like after running is my Green Smoothie bowl to reboot and recharge myself. I just go crazy and put whatever I am in the mood for. So, here it is, my bowl of super power happiness!

10k Green Smoothie!

You'll need:

1 banana Half avocado 1 cup almond milk Half cup oats 1Tbsp chia seeds 2 dates 1tsp of each: of spirulina, amla and wheatgrass

Just blend everything. It will be a very nice bright green color. Pour the mixture in to the bowl, because everything tastes better in a bowl.
Top with your favorite berries and nuts. My choice this time was goji, coconut and cacao nibs. Yum!

Note: The superfood powders I use in this recipe have a specific taste. Not everybody is used to it. I would suggest first time to add smaller amounts of them, maybe just half of a teaspoon and see how it tastes and feels. Or just enjoy the smoothie without the added powders. It'll be yum as well!

'Good morning sunshine!' I wish I'd say that, but it's been raining in Oslo for the last week and I woke up again with grey skies and yucky weather. I don't even remember when was the last time I saw the sun. But this post is not about complaining about the weather. I'm just drawing a picture in your mind. It's not only sunshines and blue skies in my life  :) I have a day off today, so I allowed myself to sleep for 10 hours! I had a super busy 6 work days in a row, so I think I deserve myself a treat and this time it was sleep. Feeling so fresh and rested now, like a new person. I love my kitchen job, but I need my rest days as well. So today it's going to be a ME day at home. Firstly blogging, then some catching up on nutrition (I'm taking a course on Coursera). Afterwards treating myself with a bath in the middle of the day, just because I can :) Now let's get back to what I really  wanted to share with you. It's about me falling in love with juicing. Yes, I love juicing. It's a good way to increase your daily veggie intake and it can taste absolutely delicious. Freshly squeezed veggie juice...Yum yum yum! Last summer we (referring to me and my boyfriend. I like to include him in my stories, because I'm incurably in-love with him and I like using WE) got ourselves a juicer. Nothing fancy, just a regular Phillips juicer, but it works fine. We made so many different juices, some of them better than others. Once I tried to juice leek, It was not a success. The only thing I don't like about juicing is the leftover pulp. I'm trying to be creative and use it for making veggies burgers or crackers, because I don't like throwing away food. Yes, I refer to leftover pulp as food. Recently I try to limit myself to juicing only a few times a week. Only because I don't want to eat leftover pulp foods every day. There are so many more better food options:) The first juice we ever made was beetroot, carrot and apple.  It was super delicious. Maybe because we're crazy about beetroot or maybe because it was our first homemade juice, but since then beetroot is very high on our juicing list. So let me introduce you to Beetrootini, winner juice at our home.   Beetrootini 2 small beetroot, 2 carrots, 2 apples half lemon or lime (both works well, whatever is available), 2cm of ginger root (or more if you like ginger).  Juice it all and serve in the martini glass for a special treat. Enjoy!       Currently I'm working on perfecting beetroot juice pulp fish cakes recipe. Will try to share my perfection soon. Happy Friday! Let's juice something yummy this weekend :) Asta

Here I am, sitting on the couch and trying to write my first ever post. I really wanted to write something special, something to wow everybody. But then I decided just to start writing whatever I feel like sharing today. And today I feel like sharing my pancakes recipe. To tell you the truth, I was never a big fan of pancakes. In my life I made them maybe just a few times and those times there not a success. I have to admit I'm pretty bad in making pancakes. Waffles I can do, but pancakes... I am never able to flip them right or to make a perfect shape. Maybe that's the reason I mostly never make them. I just don't like to make something I am not good at. Yesterday I decided to give pancakes a try again, because it was international pancakes day! It  was difficult to decide what to make. I had a few conditions. They had to be gluten free, because lately I'm trying to avoid this stuff. And they had to be savory, because I don't like sweet dinners. After checking my cabinets for ingredients and doing some research online, I decided to try  to make chickpea flour pancakes. And it was a success! I was really surprised and proud of myself. First pancake of course was a little burned and I struggled to flip it over, but the rest were fine, more than fine actually. They were not perfect shape, but the taste... it was one of the best savory pancakes I ever tried. Yum yum yum! So, here it is, the recipe for the amazing chickpea flour pancakes!

Dinner pancakes

 

300g chickpea flour

500ml water

1/2 red onion

5 garlic cloves

1 green chilli

1 tsp salt, pepper

Olive oil, butter or ghee for frying  

  Directions: Start with chopping onion, garlic and chilli in very tiny pieces. Then sift the flour and slowly mix it with water. It'll be a liquid batter, but thats ok. Then add chopped ingredients, spices and mix it well. Voila, the batter is done! Now it's time for the "hardest" part (at least for me) - to make the pancakes. Heat the frying or crepes pan. I used my cast iron pan. Add some olive oil or butter and cook like regular pancakes on both sides. I tried to make them as thin as possible, but... I'm not at that level yet. I made 8 pancakes, but if you are advanced crepes maker, you can make more! Enjoy with your favourite toppings. My choice was sautéed spinach, fried mushrooms, feta and mustard. Bon appetit!
post_title: Let's get this started... with pancakes

post_content:
I was never a big fan of pancakes. In my life I made them maybe just a few times and they there not a success. I have to admit I'm pretty bad in making pancakes. Waffles I can do, but pancakes... I am never able to flip them right or to make a perfect shape. Maybe that's the reason I mostly never make them. But today I decided to give them a try again. It's international pancakes day! So here I am in my kitchen and making gluten free savory pancakes. Nothing sweet, because dinner for me always has to be savory.  

Here is the recipe. 
 
World famous dinner pancakes 
280g chickpea flour
500ml water
1/2 red onion 
5 garlic cloves
1 green chilli
1tsp salt
1tsp cayenne pepper
1/2tsp black pepper

For the filling/serving :
15 Mushrooms
Spinach
50g Feta

Yes, I love juicing. It's a good way to increase your daily veggie intake and it can taste absolutely delicious. Freshly squeezed veggie juice...Yum yum yum! Last summer we (referring to me and my boyfriend. I like to include him in my stories, because I'm incurably in-love with him and I like using WE) got ourselves a juicer. Nothing fancy, just a regular Phillips juicer, but it works fine. We made so many different juices, some of them better than others. Once I tried to juice leek, It was not a success. The only thing I don't like about juicing is the leftover pulp. I'm trying to be creative and use it for making veggies burgers or crackers, because I don't like throwing away food. Yes, I refer to leftover pulp as food. Recently I try to limit myself to juicing only a few times a week. Only because I don't want to eat leftover pulp foods every day. There are so many more better food options:) The first juice we ever made was beetroot, carrot and apple.  It was super delicious. Maybe because we're crazy about beetroot or maybe because it was our first homemade juice, but since then beetroot is very high on our juicing list. So let me introduce you to Beetrootini, winner juice at our home. 
Beetrootini
 2 small beetroot
 2 carrots
 2 apples
 half lemon or lime (both works well, whatever is available)
 2cm of ginger root (or more if you like ginger)
 Juice it all and serve in the martini glass for a special treat. Enjoy!
Currently I'm working on perfecting beetroot juice pulp fish cakes recipe. Will try to share my perfection soon. Happy Friday! Let's juice something yummy this weekend :) Asta

Here I am, sitting on the couch and trying to write my first ever post. I really wanted to write something special, something to wow everybody. But then I decided just to start writing whatever I feel like sharing today. And today I feel like sharing my pancakes recipe. To tell you the truth, I was never a big fan of pancakes. In my life I made them maybe just a few times and those times there not a success. I have to admit I'm pretty bad in making pancakes. Waffles I can do, but pancakes... I am never able to flip them right or to make a perfect shape. Maybe that's the reason I mostly never make them. I just don't like to make something I am not good at. Yesterday I decided to give pancakes a try again, because it was international pancakes day! It  was difficult to decide what to make. I had a few conditions. They had to be gluten free, because lately I'm trying to avoid this stuff. And they had to be savory, because I don't like sweet dinners. After checking my cabinets for ingredients and doing some research online, I decided to try  to make chickpea flour pancakes. And it was a success! I was really surprised and proud of myself. First pancake of course was a little burned and I struggled to flip it over, but the rest were fine, more than fine actually. They were not perfect shape, but the taste... it was one of the best savory pancakes I ever tried. Yum yum yum! So, here it is, the recipe for the amazing chickpea flour pancakes! 
Dinner pancakes
 
 300g chickpea flour
 500ml water
 1/2 red onion
 5 garlic cloves
 1 green chilli
 1tsp salt
 1tsp cayenne pepper
 1/2tsp black pepper
 Olive oil, butter or ghee for frying  

Directions:
Start with chopping onion, garlic and chilli in very tiny pieces.
Then sift the flour and slowly mix it with water. 
It'll be a liquid batter, but thats ok.
Then add chopped ingredients, spices and mix it well. Voila, the batter is done!
Now it's time for the "hardest" part (at least for me) - to make the pancakes.
Heat the frying or crepes pan. I used my cast iron pan. 
Add some olive oil or butter and cook like regular pancakes on both sides. 
I tried to make them as thin as possible, but... I'm not at that level yet. 
I made 8 pancakes, but if you are advanced crepes maker, you can make more! 
Enjoy with your favourite toppings. 
My choice was sautéed spinach, fried mushrooms, feta and mustard. 
Bon appetit!
post_title: Let's get this started... with pancakes

post_content:
I love breakfast. Either it's eggs or oatmeal, or superfood powered smoothie, I'll take it. For the last year I had developed this routine . Wake up at 6am. Glass of hot lemon water. Gym time. Shower. Breakfast around 8am - smoothie or oatmeal. And then work at 10am. But two weeks ago I changed jobs and my routine got different. Some days I'm starting work at 7am. And I don't feel like waking up before 6am just to have time to make breakfast. I choose sleep. Therefore I looked in to some alternatives and gave a try to overnight oats. I tried them before a few times and liked them. But I never appreciated what a life saver they really are! It takes less than 5min to prepare them the night before. In the morning you just need to open the fridge, put the jar in your bag and you are good to go. You can eat them on the bus, metro or at your workplace. Brilliant! And they taste great, and you get all your nutritions to start a day. And we like nutritions, right?

So here it is, my jar o' oats!

1 banana 2/3 cups of oats 1Tbsp chia seeds 1Tbsp goji berries 2Tbsp dried mulberries 1 cup your choice of milk (I use oat milk) 1 glass jar. Mine is 0.5 liter.
Instructions: On the bottom of the jar put 1/3 sliced banana. Top it with 1/3 of oats, chia, goji and mulberries. Cover everything with 1/3 of milk. And repeat this two more times. There should be plenty of liquid in the jar. Oats  and chia seeds will soak most of it.   Now cover the jar and put it in the fridge overnight. In the morning just put the jar in your bag and you are good to go. No more excuses 'I have no time for breakfast'. It literally takes less than 5min to make it. You don't need to measure ingriedients when you make it. Just add layers of oats, chia, whatever berries or fruit you want and enough liquid to cover everything. Give it a try!

Afterwards treating myself with a bath in the middle of the day, just because I can :) Now let's get back to what I really  wanted to share with you. It's about me falling in love with juicing. Yes, I love juicing. It's a good way to increase your daily veggie intake and it can taste absolutely delicious. Freshly squeezed veggie juice...Yum yum yum! Last summer we (referring to me and my boyfriend. I like to include him in my stories, because I'm incurably in-love with him and I like using WE) got ourselves a juicer. Nothing fancy, just a regular Phillips juicer, but it works fine. We made so many different juices, some of them better than others. Once I tried to juice leek, It was not a success. The only thing I don't like about juicing is the leftover pulp. I'm trying to be creative and use it for making veggies burgers or crackers, because I don't like throwing away food. Yes, I refer to leftover pulp as food. Recently I try to limit myself to juicing only a few times a week. Only because I don't want to eat leftover pulp foods every day. There are so many more better food options:) The first juice we ever made was beetroot, carrot and apple.  It was super delicious. Maybe because we're crazy about beetroot or maybe because it was our first homemade juice, but since then beetroot is very high on our juicing list. So let me introduce you to Beetrootini, winner juice at our home.   Beetrootini 2 small beetroot, 2 carrots, 2 apples half lemon or lime (both works well, whatever is available), 2cm of ginger root (or more if you like ginger). Juice it all and serve in the martini glass for a special treat. Enjoy!       Currently I'm working on perfecting beetroot juice pulp fish cakes recipe. Will try to share my perfection soon. Happy Friday! Let's juice something yummy this weekend :) Asta

Here I am, sitting on the couch and trying to write my first ever post. I really wanted to write something special, something to wow everybody. But then I decided just to start writing whatever I feel like sharing today. And today I feel like sharing my pancakes recipe. To tell you the truth, I was never a big fan of pancakes. In my life I made them maybe just a few times and those times there not a success. I have to admit I'm pretty bad in making pancakes. Waffles I can do, but pancakes... I am never able to flip them right or to make a perfect shape. Maybe that's the reason I mostly never make them. I just don't like to make something I am not good at. Yesterday I decided to give pancakes a try again, because it was international pancakes day! It  was difficult to decide what to make. I had a few conditions. They had to be gluten free, because lately I'm trying to avoid this stuff. And they had to be savory, because I don't like sweet dinners. After checking my cabinets for ingredients and doing some research online, I decided to try  to make chickpea flour pancakes. And it was a success! I was really surprised and proud of myself. First pancake of course was a little burned and I struggled to flip it over, but the rest were fine, more than fine actually. They were not perfect shape, but the taste... it was one of the best savory pancakes I ever tried. Yum yum yum! So, here it is, the recipe for the amazing chickpea flour pancakes!

Dinner pancakes

 

300g chickpea flour

500ml water

1/2 red onion

5 garlic cloves

1 green chilli

1 tsp salt, pepper

Olive oil, butter or ghee for frying  

  Directions: Start with chopping onion, garlic and chilli in very tiny pieces. Then sift the flour and slowly mix it with water. It'll be a liquid batter, but thats ok. Then add chopped ingredients, spices and mix it well. Voila, the batter is done! Now it's time for the "hardest" part (at least for me) - to make the pancakes. Heat the frying or crepes pan. I used my cast iron pan. Add some olive oil or butter and cook like regular pancakes on both sides. I tried to make them as thin as possible, but... I'm not at that level yet. I made 8 pancakes, but if you are advanced crepes maker, you can make more! Enjoy with your favourite toppings. My choice was sautéed spinach, fried mushrooms, feta and mustard. Bon appetit!
post_title: Let's get this started... with pancakes

post_content: 'Good morning sunshine!' I wish I'd say that, but it's been raining in Oslo for the last week and I woke up again with grey skies and yucky weather. I don't even remember when was the last time I saw the sun. But this post is not about complaining about the weather. I'm just drawing a picture in your mind. It's not only sunshines and blue skies in my life  :) I have a day off today, so I allowed myself to sleep for 10 hours! I had a super busy 6 work days in a row, so I think I deserve myself a treat and this time it was sleep. Feeling so fresh and rested now, like a new person. I love my kitchen job, but I need my rest days as well. So today it's going to be a ME day at home. Firstly blogging, then some catching up on nutrition (I'm taking a course on Coursera). Afterwards treating myself with a bath in the middle of the day, just because I can :) Now let's get back to what I really  wanted to share with you. It's about me falling in love with juicing. Yes, I love juicing. It's a good way to increase your daily veggie intake and it can taste absolutely delicious. Freshly squeezed veggie juice...Yum yum yum! Last summer we (referring to me and my boyfriend. I like to include him in my stories, because I'm incurably in-love with him and I like using WE) got ourselves a juicer. Nothing fancy, just a regular Phillips juicer, but it works fine. We made so many different juices, some of them better than others. Once I tried to juice leek, It was not a success. The only thing I don't like about juicing is the leftover pulp. I'm trying to be creative and use it for making veggies burgers or crackers, because I don't like throwing away food. Yes, I refer to leftover pulp as food. Recently I try to limit myself to juicing only a few times a week. Only because I don't want to eat leftover pulp foods every day. There are so many more better food options:) The first juice we ever made was beetroot, carrot and apple.  It was super delicious. Maybe because we're crazy about beetroot or maybe because it was our first homemade juice, but since then beetroot is very high on our juicing list. So let me introduce you to Beetrootini, winner juice at our home.   Beetrootini 2 small beetroot, 2 carrots, 2 apples half lemon or lime (both works well, whatever is available), 2cm of ginger root (or more if you like ginger).  Juice it all and serve in the martini glass for a special treat. Enjoy!       Currently I'm working on perfecting beetroot juice pulp fish cakes recipe. Will try to share my perfection soon. Happy Friday! Let's juice something yummy this weekend :) Asta

I love breakfast. Either it's eggs or oatmeal, or superfood powered smoothie, I'll take it. For the last year I had developed this routine . Wake up at 6am. Glass of hot lemon water. Gym time. Shower. Breakfast around 8am - smoothie or oatmeal. And then work at 10am. But two weeks ago I changed jobs and my routine got different. Some days I'm starting work at 7am. And I don't feel like waking up before 6am just to have time to make breakfast. I choose sleep. Therefore I looked in to some alternatives and gave a try to overnight oats. I tried them before a few times and liked them. But I never appreciated what a life saver they really are! It takes less than 5min to prepare them the night before. In the morning you just need to open the fridge, put the jar in your bag and you are good to go. You can eat them on the bus, metro or at your workplace. Brilliant! And they taste great, and you get all your nutritions to start a day. And we like nutritions, right?

So here it is, my Life Saving Breakfast!

  1 banana 2/3 cups of oats 1Tbsp chia seeds 1Tbsp goji berries 2Tbsp dried mulberries 1 cup your choice of milk (I use oat milk) 1 glass jar. Mine is 0.5 liter.     Instructions: On the bottom of the jar put 1/3 sliced banana. Top it with 1/3 of oats, chia, goji and mulberries. Cover everything with 1/3 of milk. And repeat this two more times. The stuff in the jar should be liquid. That's how mine looked like in the picture below.   Now cover the jar and put it in the fridge overnight. In the morning just put the jar in your bag and you are good to go. No more excuses 'I have no time for breakfast'. It literally takes less than 5min to make it. You don't need to measure when you make it. Just add layers of oats, chia, whatever berries or fruit you want and enough liquid to cover everything. Give it a try!
post_title: Life changing breakfast for busy people

'Life is not about making others happy. Life is about sharing your happiness with others.'
I would like to share with you all the people who inspired me to start this blog and share my healthy food creations, positive ideas and other joys of life.  My biggest inspiration is Love. I'm grateful and fortunate that I have the most amazing person to share my life with. I have the best boyfriend ever, and who makes me feel happy every single day. Without his help and support, I would have never started this blog. Another my inspiration is my good friend Claudia. She is the nicest and most sincere person ever. And she knows a bunch about holistic nutrition, healthy foods, balanced life, yoga, travelling and so much more. I can always count on her for a life advice. You can find her on Instagram if you want to know more about holistic nutrition or you need some tips for balancing your life. She has an amazing travel blog as well! I recently met a super nice foodie, blogger and chef Julie. She is not only writing a very popular food blog in Norway and has her own Chiku catering business, but she is also a really friendly and nice person. I am learning a lot from her. Check out her blog for food inspirations! I am lucky I have met another foodie, who tries to make a positive change in people's life and offer them healthier, ecological eats and pressed juices.  I think she should start her own food blog, but until then check out her Instagram profile: Pur Oslo! I admire and get inspired from her posts every day. Some other sources of my inspiration come from the Green Kitchen Stories website. It's my favourite food blog! All their recipes are amazing and nicely presented.  I would love to have the couple behind that website over for dinner. The last person, I would like to mention is Elri. I've never met her in person, but from following her on Instagram and reading her blog, I feel like I know her. She has a very similar positive attitude towards life and food and she seems like a very warm and sincere person. If you are looking for a holistic health coach, contact her! Hugs <3 Asta

All their recipes are amazing and nicely presented.  I would love to have the couple behind that website over for dinner. The last person, I would like to mention is Elri. I've never met her in person, but from following her on Instagram and reading her blog, I feel like I know her. She has a very similar positive attitude towards life and food and she seems like a very warm and sincere person. If you are looking for a holistic health coach, contact her! Hugs <3 Asta
post_title: All the people who inspired me to start this blog

post_content:
'Life is not about making others happy. Life is about sharing your happiness with others.'
I would like to share with you all the people who inspired me to start this blog and share my healthy food creations, positive vibes and other joys of life.  My biggest inspiration is Love. I'm grateful and feel blessed that I have the most amazing person to share my life with. I have the best boyfriend ever, and who makes me feel happy every single day. Without his help and support, I would have never started this blog. Another my inspiration is my good friend Claudia. She is the nicest and most sincere person ever. And she knows all the stuff about holistic nutrition, healthy foods, balanced life, yoga, travelling and so much more. I can always count on her for a life advice. You can contact her on Instagram if you want to know more about holistic nutrition or you need some tips for balancing your life. She has an amazing travel blog as well! I recently met super nice foodie, blogger and chef Julie. She is not only writing a very popular food blog in Norway, have her own Chiku catering business, but she is as well super friendly and nice person. I am learning a lot from her. Check out her blog for food inspirations! I am lucky I have met another foodie, who tries to make a positive change in people's life and offer them healthier, ecological eats and pressed juices.  I think she should start her own food blog, but until then check out her Instagram profile: Pur Oslo! post_title: All the people who inspired me to start this blog

post_content:
Happy Monday! Hope everybody had a lovely weekend. I was working on Saturday.  In the evening I had a date night at home with my boyfriend. But Sunday was a special day to me. It was our 3 years anniversary. Woohoo! Three years of love and happiness! Who said love lasts only three years? I believe ours will last forever. Yep, I'm still inlove and see the world threw pink glasses. We went to Smalhans for anniversary dinner. Great food, surprising wine list and nice personnel. Definitely going back there again! We took plenty of pictures. The place deserves a separate blog post. I love having date nights with my love. Yummy food, a glass of red wine and a movie. Perfect! Last Saturday we had House of Cards marathon. I really like this tv show. Kevin Spacey is brilliant. I love his acting, especially his occasional remarks and glances straight to the camera. We never manage to watch only one episode, because the show gets you hooked and you want to know what happens next. If you haven't seen this show, give it a try! You can find it on Netflix. Tacos were on the menu to go with the show. We usually make them once a month. I especially love homemade salsa and guacamole! But let me tell you, it takes time to make Mexican food if you want to do everything by yourself. Of course you can buy everything prepared and packaged: tortillas, taco shells, salsa, guacamole. But I believe that home cooked meal, made from scratch with no rush and lots of love will always taste better. Furthermore you can use whatever ingredients you want and avoid preservatives. In most of the cases it'll be much healthier. And we want to be healthy and happy, right? Recently I was experimenting with low carb and gluten free taco shells. Flax seed tacos are our favorite at the moment - rich in fiber and taste great with salsa, minced meat and guacamole. And you need just a few ingredients. It's not very easy to make them, but they are so worth it your time and frustration. Let me share with you my tips for making taco shells from flax seeds.

Flaxseed Taco Shells

  You'll need: 1 cup flaxseeds 1/4 cup sunflower seeds 1tsp cayenne pepper 1/4 red onion 1 clove garlic 1/2 red pepper salt and pepper to taste (about 1tsp each) Directions: 1. Mix flaxseeds with sunflower seeds and soak them overnight in 1.5 cups of water. Flax seeds will soak most of the water. The mixture will look like a pudding. 2. Put the mixture in the blender with the rest ingredients and blend everything to a dough. Set the dough in the fridge for half an hour 3. Now it's the most difficult part - to roll the dough and make taco shells. It'll be very sticky. I tried to roll it between two different baking papers. It works ok. Recently I took different approach. I cut the baking paper in the size of taco shells I wish to have, put some of the dough, cover it with plastic and flatten it with my fingers. This technique works best for me. 4. Preheat the oven to 160 degress. Set the flat shells on the baking tray and bake them in the oven for about 40min. They should become dry and not sticky anymore. Then it's time to make them look like real taco shells. It's pretty easy. Just fold them in half and bake for another 15min or so until they become totally dry.  Remove the paper and enjoy them with your favorite taco fillings. I always go for salsa, guacamole and minced meat. Yum! Note: the baking time will depend on taco shells size, thickness and your oven. Check once in a while to see if they became dry and non-sticky. After folding them it takes only 10-15min to complete drying them. I made 9 pretty big taco shells. I think you could make around 12 smaller ones. It will be a sequel to this post with ridiculously spicy Allan's salsa recipe. In a few days! Bon appétit! Asta
post_title: What happens during weekend, comes out on blog on Monday! ( +Flaxseed Tacos recipe)

post_content:

post_content:
"You see, there are still faint glimmers of civilization left in this barbaric slaughter house that was once known as humanity" - The Grand Budapest Hotel
Happy Hump Day! Hope you're having a wonderful week so far. Last night we went to the cinema to watch a new Wes Anderson movie - The Grand Budapest Hotel. I thought it was simply wonderful, funny, exciting, colorful and Brilliant! It is definitely one of the best movies I've seen so far. I literally enjoyed every single minute of it. If you haven't seen it yet, I highly recommend!   This movie reminded me of another excellent movies  by Wes Anderson - Moonrise Kingdom and Fantastic Mr. Fox. They are as well quirky, sweet, beautiful and funny. I want to watch them again! I think it's a good trio for a movie night with your friends. Charming, colorful movies which make you laugh and feel happy! If you're planning a movie night, you'll need some food, right? I suggest having tacos, because I like Mexican food.  I already posted my flax seed tacos and salsa recipes. And here goes my holy guacamole recipe. Simple, easy and super delicious! If you don't have time to make tacos, you can always use salsa and guacamole as yummy dips for chips or veggies for your movie night!

Holy Guacamoly

You'll need:

4 ripe avocados Half of red onion 1 lime Handful of cherry tomatoes Bunch of fresh coriander 1 tsp of each: salt, cumin and cayenne pepper     Directions:  1. Finely chop onion, coriander and cherry tomatoes. 2. Mash avocados with the spices, half of onions and tomatoes. Use hand masher or blender. 3. And the rest of chopped onions and tomatoes, squeeze the lime juice and mix well. I always leave some onions and tomatoes non mashed. I like some crunchy bites in my guacamole. 4. Adjust salt, pepper and lime. Voila! Enjoy on the toast, with your tacos or as a dip. Sorry, no picture of the guacamole this time. The quality was not so good. But trust me, the taste is great! Will add the picture later, the next time I make it again. It'll be soon. I love guacamole. Have a wonderful the rest of the week  my lovelies! Don't forget to be Happy! Asta
post_title: Wes Anderson movie night (+ Holy Guacamoly recipe)

post_content:
Today I was thinking about my life in Norway, about friends, family and what does it mean to live in a foreign country. I moved to Norway more than four years ago. My sister got a job offer in Oslo and I had an opportunity to come and finish my master studies at BI. It was easy to decide since my sister was going to move to the same city at the same time. I really wanted to study abroad and the timing seemed perfect. I think it was meant to be. In the last four years many things happened in my life. I graduated, found my love, made new friends and finally figured out what I want to do in my life. I'm not sure how my life would have been if I stayed in Lithuania. But I am happy now and that is all what matters to me. Living abroad is not easy. The beginning was tough. Suddenly I was in a new place where I didn't know anything, I didn't know culture, people, places, language. I had to invest my time and energy in learning, meeting new people and making new friends outside my comfort zone. It was really difficult to be far away from my very good friends, whom I knew since my childhood. I missed them a lot and still do. I was always glad to meet new people with different backgrounds and experiences. But I don't believe you can become friends over night. For me it takes time to open up and let people in to my heart. I believe in quality and not quantity of friends. Even if I miss my Lithuanian friends and think about them quite often, after four years in Norway I can say that I have met people here whom I call friends now and believe that our connection will last forever. I feel like I belong here. Home is where my heart is. And it is in Oslo now. The best thing about living in international Oslo, is that you get to meet people from all over the world, you get to know their culture, traditions and food! It's not a surprise, I love food! And I like to get to know people over a home cooked meal and a good glass of wine. I would like to share some of the recipes I got from my friends. Because they are just too good to be kept in secret!
Friends who eat together, stay together!
Let's start with my friend Allan. He is a very nice guy from Texas, whom I was lucky to meet in Oslo. It was sad that he had to move back to the States, but I believe that I'll see him again. He shared with me his salsa recipe. I've been using it for the last half a year. Trust me, it's really good! Texicans know their tex-mex food. I haven't made any other salsa since. It's definitely a winner at our home. Though it is crazy spicy! If you are up for the challenge, here is the recipe:

Allan's salsa

You'll need: 2 handfulls of cherry tomatoes (I used 16) 5 fresh jalapenos 1 fresh habanero Juice of 1 lime 1 green pepper 1 red onion 3 cloves garlic 1 can of cherry tomatoes (400g) Handfull of fresh coriander 1 tsp of each: salt, pepper, cumin Directions: 1. Chop green pepper and heavily char it in the frying pan. It should be black and blistered. 2. Remove seeds from jalapeños  and habanero. 3. Peel and chop red onion in a few pieces. 4. Put all the ingredients in the blender and blend it until desired consistency. I like my salsa very well blended. Voila! Note: It is really spicy! If you are not used to spicy food, I would suggest to use only half of habanero and less jalapeños at the beginning. You can always add more later. Salsa can stay in the air tight container in the fridge for up to five days.
post_title: Good friends, good food, good times. Allan's salsa

post_content:
I love breakfast. Either it's eggs or oatmeal, or superfood powered smoothie, I'll take it. For the last year I had developed this routine . Wake up at 6am. Glass of hot lemon water. Gym time. Shower. Breakfast around 8am - smoothie or oatmeal. And then work at 10am. But two weeks ago I changed jobs and my routine got different. Some days I'm starting work at 7am. And I don't feel like waking up before 6am just to have time to make breakfast. I choose sleep. Therefore I looked in to some alternatives and gave a try to overnight oats. I tried them before a few times and liked them. But I never appreciated what a life saver they really are! It takes less than 5min to prepare them the night before. In the morning you just need to open the fridge, put the jar in your bag and you are good to go. You can eat them on the bus, metro or at your workplace. Brilliant! And they taste great, and you get all your nutritions to start a day. And we like nutritions, right?

So here it is, my jar o' oats!

1 banana 2/3 cups of oats 1Tbsp chia seeds 1Tbsp goji berries 2Tbsp dried mulberries 1 cup your choice of milk (I use oat milk) 1 glass jar. Mine is 0.5 liter.
Instructions: On the bottom of the jar put 1/3 sliced banana. Top it with 1/3 of oats, chia, goji and mulberries. Cover everything with 1/3 of milk. And repeat this two more times. There should be plenty of liquid in the jar. Oats  and chia seeds will soak most of it.   Now cover the jar and put it in the fridge overnight. In the morning just put the jar in your bag and you are good to go. No more excuses 'I have no time for breakfast'. It literally takes less than 5min to make it. You don't need to measure ingriedients when you make it. Just add layers of oats, chia, whatever berries or fruit you want and enough liquid to cover everything. Give it a try!

Today I woke up to a beautiful morning, sunny, blue skies, and I said to myself: 'Today is the day when it all begins, let's do this' I put on my asics, turned on my iPod, set the Garmin watch and I was ready. Ready to run! And I went to the park and ran 5k. My body was fighting me and telling: 'just stop, it's cold, it hurts, I can't do it'. But I chose to listen to my happy and positive side: 'it's only 5k, you don't have to run fast, just take your time and you'll be fine. Think about all the joy and feeling of accomplishment afterwards'. And I ran my 5k and I didn't stop. Hurra! Let me tell you, running is not my thing, not yet. I love going to the gym, cycling, hiking and other active ways of spending time. But running is tough for me. I don't enjoy it, yet. But last year I started to run. My boyfriend Lucas is addictive runner and I was always curious why he likes running so much. So last year I signed myself for Oslo marathon to run 10k. I needed some motivation to start running, some goal. It was to run 10k under 1 hour. It's not very big accomplishment for most of the people. But I have never ran 10k in my life! So for me it was a big deal. Long story short, after summer spending running I managed to run 10k in 48:44! I was super proud for myself. It was a big accomplishemnt for me. So this year I set myself another goal. To run half marathon. I wanted to say it out load, so I won't have an excuse to quit. And my preparations started today, with 5k. I didn't run since last september, so I took it slow. And to tell you the truth,I don't think I could have ran more. It was tough. But it's better than nothing. I still have lots of time till Oslo marathon in september, right? I will keep you all updated how it goes. One thing what I really like after running is my Smoothie bowl to recover and get nutritions and energy to continue the day. I just go crazy and put whatever I am in the mood for. So, here it is, my bowl of super power happiness!

Super breakfast bowl!

You'll need:

1 banana

Half avocado

1 cup almond milk

Half cup oats

1Tbsp chia seeds

2 dates

1tsp of spirulina, amla and wheatgrass

Topping: goji, coconut and cacao nibs

Super breakfast bowl!

You'll need:

1 banana

Half avocado

1 cup almond milk

Half cup oats

1Tbsp chia seeds

2 dates

1tsp of spirulina, amla and wheatgrass

Just blend everything. It will be a very nice bright green color. Pour the mixture in the bowl, because everything tastes better in a bowl.

Top with your favorite berries and nuts. My choice this time was goji, coconut and cacao nibs. Yum!

Note: The superfood powders I use in this recipe have a specific taste. Not everybody is used to it. I would suggest first time to add smaller amounts of them,maybe just half of teaspoon and see how it tastes and feels. Or just enjoy the smoothie without the added powders. It'll be yum as well!

Today I woke up to a beautiful morning, sunny, blue skies, and I said to myself: 'Today is the day when it all begins, let's do this'. I put on my asics, turned on my iPod, set the Garmin watch and I was ready. Ready to run! And I went to the park and ran 5k. My body was fighting me and telling: 'just stop, it's cold, it hurts, I can't do it'. But I chose to listen to my happy and positive side: 'it's only 5k, you don't have to run fast, just take your time and you'll be fine. Think about all the joy and feeling of accomplishment afterwards'. And I ran my 5k and I didn't stop. Hurra! Let me tell you, running is not my thing, not yet. I love going to the gym, cycling, hiking and other active ways of spending time. But running is tough for me. I don't enjoy it, yet. But last year I started to run. My boyfriend Lucas is addicted to running and I was always curious why he likes running so much. So last year I signed myself for Oslo marathon to run 10k. I needed some motivation to start running, some goal. It was to run 10k under 1 hour. It's not very big accomplishment for most of the people. But I have never ran 10k in my life! So for me it was a big deal. Long story short, after summer spending running I managed to run 10k in 48:44! I was super proud for myself. It was a big accomplishemnt for me. So this year I set myself another goal. To run half marathon. I wanted to say it out load, so I won't have an excuse to quit. And my preparations started today, with 5k. I didn't run since last september, so I took it slow. And to tell you the truth,I don't think I could have ran more. It was tough. But it's better than nothing. I still have lots of time till Oslo marathon in september, right? I will keep you all updated how it goes. One thing what I really like after running is my Smoothie bowl to recover and get nutritions and energy to continue the day. I just go crazy and put whatever I am in the mood for. So, here it is, my bowl of super power happiness!

But I chose to listen to my happy and positive side: 'it's only 5k, you don't have to run fast, just take your time and you'll be fine. Think about all the joy and feeling of accomplishment afterwards'. And I ran my 5k and I didn't stop. Hurra! Let me tell you, running is not my thing, not yet. I love going to the gym, cycling, hiking and other active ways of spending time. But running is tough for me. I don't enjoy it, yet. But last year I started to run. My boyfriend Lucas is addicted to running and I was always curious why he likes running so much. So last year I signed myself for Oslo marathon to run 10k. I needed some motivation to start running, some goal. It was to run 10k under 1 hour. It's not very big accomplishment for most of the people. But I have never ran 10k in my life! So for me it was a big deal. Long story short, after summer spending running I managed to run 10k in 48:44! I was super proud for myself. It was a big accomplishemnt for me. So this year I set myself another goal. To run half marathon. I wanted to say it out load, so I won't have an excuse to quit. And my preparations started today, with 5k. I didn't run since last september, so I took it slow. And to tell you the truth,I don't think I could have ran more. It was tough. But it's better than nothing. I still have lots of time till Oslo marathon in september, right? I will keep you all updated how it goes. One thing what I really like after running is my Smoothie bowl to recover and get nutritions and energy to continue the day. I just go crazy and put whatever I am in the mood for. So, here it is, my bowl of super power happiness!

Super breakfast bowl!

You'll need:

1 banana Half avocado 1 cup almond milk Half cup oats 1Tbsp chia seeds 2 dates 1tsp of spirulina, amla and wheatgrass

Just blend everything. It will be a very nice bright green color. Pour the mixture in the bowl, because everything tastes better in a bowl.

Top with your favorite berries and nuts. My choice this time was goji, coconut and cacao nibs. Yum!

Note: The superfood powders I use in this recipe have a specific taste. Not everybody is used to it. I would suggest first time to add smaller amounts of them,maybe just half of teaspoon and see how it tastes and feels. Or just enjoy the smoothie without the added powders. It'll be yum as well!

post_content: Last night we had a Mexican feast. I love salsa and guacamole! But let me tell you, it takes time to make mexican food if you want to do everything yourself. Nowadays you can buy everything prepared: tortillas, taco shells, salsa, guacamole. But the home cooked meal, made from scratch with no rush and lots of love will always taste better. It has to be prepared with time and love. Recently I was experimenting with low carb and gluten free taco shells. Flax seed taco shells are our favorite at the moment - rich in fiber and taste great with salsa, minced meat and guacamole.   It's not very easy to make them, but they are so worth it your time and frustration. Let me share with you my tips for making taco shells from flax seeds. You'll need: 1 cup flaxseeds 1/4 cup sunflower seeds 1tsp cayenne pepper 1/4 red onion 1 clove garlic 1/2 red pepper salt and pepper to taste (about 1tsp each) Directions: 1. Mix flaxseeds with sunflower seeds and soak them overnight in 1.5 cups of water. Flax seeds will soak most of the water. The mixture will look like a pudding. 2. Put the mixture in the blender with the rest ingredients and blend everything to a dough. Set the dough in the fridge for half an hour. 3. Now it's the most difficult part - to roll the dough and make taco shells. It'll be very sticky. I tried to roll it between two different baking papers. It works ok. Recently I took different approach. I cut the baking paper in the size of taco shells I wish to have, put some of the dough, cover it with plastic and flatten it with your fingers. This technique works best for me.
post_title: Texan feast with flax seed taco shells

post_content: Last night we had a Mexican feast. I love salsa and guacamole! But let me tell you, it takes time to make mexican food if you want to do everything yourself. Nowadays you can buy everything prepared: tortillas, taco shells, salsa, guacamole. But the home cooked meal, made from scratch with no rush and lots of love will always taste better. It has to be prepared with time and love. Recently I was experimenting with low carb and gluten free taco shells. Flax seed taco shells are our favorite at the moment - rich in fiber and taste great with salsa, minced meat and guacamole.   It's not very easy to make them, but they are so worth it your time and frustration. Let me share with you my tips for making taco shells from flax seeds. You'll need: 1 cup flaxseeds 1/4 cup sunflower seeds 1tsp cayenne pepper 1/4 red onion 1 clove garlic 1/2 red pepper salt and pepper to taste (about 1tsp each) Directions: 1. Mix flaxseeds with sunflower seeds and soak them overnight in 1.5 cups of water. Flax seeds will soak most of the water. The mixture will look like a pudding. 2. Put the mixture in the blender with the rest ingredients and blend everything to a dough. Set the dough in the fridge for half an hour. 3. Now it's the most difficult part - to roll the dough and make taco shells. It'll be very sticky. I tried to roll it between two different baking papers. It works ok. Recently I took different approach. I cut the baking paper in the size of taco shells I wish to have, put some of the dough, cover it with plastic and flatten it with your fingers. This technique works best for me.  4. Preheat the oven to 160 degress. Set the flat shells on the baking tray and bake them in the oven for about 40min.  Check when they become dry and not sticky anymore. Then it's time to make them look like real taco shells. It's pretty easy. Just fold them in U shape and bake for another 15min or so until they become totally dry.
post_title: Texan feast with flax seed taco shells

post_content: Last night we had a Mexican feast. I love salsa and guacamole! But let me tell you, it takes time to make mexican food if you want to do everything yourself. Nowadays you can buy everything prepared: tortillas, taco shells, salsa, guacamole. But the home cooked meal, made from scratch with no rush and lots of love will always taste better. It has to be prepared with time and love. Recently I was experimenting with low carb and gluten free taco shells. Flax seed taco shells are our favorite at the moment - rich in fiber and taste great with salsa, minced meat and guacamole.   It's not very easy to make them, but they are so worth it your time and frustration. Let me share with you my tips for making taco shells from flax seeds. You'll need: 1 cup flaxseeds 1/4 cup sunflower seeds 1tsp cayenne pepper 1/4 red onion 1 clove garlic 1/2 red pepper salt and pepper to taste (about 1tsp each) Directions: 1. Mix flaxseeds with sunflower seeds and soak them overnight in 1.5 cups of water. Flax seeds will soak most of the water. The mixture will look like a pudding. 2. Put the mixture in the blender with the rest ingredients and blend everything to a dough. Set the dough in the fridge for half an hour. 3. Now it's the most difficult part - to roll the dough and make taco shells. It'll be very sticky. I tried to roll it between two different baking papers. It works ok. Recently I took different approach. I cut the baking paper in the size of taco shells I wish to have, put some of the dough, cover it with plastic and flatten it with your fingers. This technique works best for me.  4. Preheat the oven to 160 degress. Set the flat shells on the baking tray and bake them in the oven for about 40min.  Check when they become dry and not sticky anymore. Then it's time to make them look like real taco shells. It's pretty easy. Just fold them in half and bake for another 15min or so until they become totally dry.  Remove the paper and enjoy them with your favorite taco fillings. I always go for salsa, guacamole and minced meat.   Note: the baking time will depend on taco shells size, thickness and your oven. Check once in a while to see if they became dry and non-sticky. After folding them it takes only 10-15min to complete drying them. I made 9 pretty big taco shells. I think you could make around 12 smaller ones. It will be a sequel to this post with famous Allan's salsa recipe. Bon appétit! Asta
post_title: Texan feast with flax seed taco shells

post_content: Last night we had a Mexican feast. I love salsa and guacamole! But let me tell you, it takes time to make mexican food if you want to do everything by yourself. Of course you can buy everything prepared and packaged: tortillas, taco shells, salsa, guacamole. But I believe that home cooked meal, made from scratch with no rush and lots of love will always taste better. Futhermore you can use whatever ingredients you want and avoid preservatives. In most of the cases it'll be much healthier. And we want to be healthy and happy, right? Recently I was experimenting with low carb and gluten free taco shells. Flax seed taco shells are our favorite at the moment - rich in fiber and taste great with salsa, minced meat and guacamole. And you need just a few ingredients. It's not very easy to make them, but they are so worth it your time and frustration. Let me share with you my tips for making taco shells from flax seeds. You'll need: 1 cup flaxseeds 1/4 cup sunflower seeds 1tsp cayenne pepper 1/4 red onion 1 clove garlic 1/2 red pepper salt and pepper to taste (about 1tsp each) Directions: 1. Mix flaxseeds with sunflower seeds and soak them overnight in 1.5 cups of water. Flax seeds will soak most of the water. The mixture will look like a pudding. 2. Put the mixture in the blender with the rest ingredients and blend everything to a dough. Set the dough in the fridge for half an hour. 3. Now it's the most difficult part - to roll the dough and make taco shells. It'll be very sticky. I tried to roll it between two different baking papers. It works ok. Recently I took different approach. I cut the baking paper in the size of taco shells I wish to have, put some of the dough, cover it with plastic and flatten it with your fingers. This technique works best for me.   4. Preheat the oven to 160 degress. Set the flat shells on the baking tray and bake them in the oven for about 40min.  Check when they become dry and not sticky anymore. Then it's time to make them look like real taco shells. It's pretty easy. Just fold them in half and bake for another 15min or so until they become totally dry.  Remove the paper and enjoy them with your favorite taco fillings. I always go for salsa, guacamole and minced meat. Yum! Note: the baking time will depend on taco shells size, thickness and your oven. Check once in a while to see if they became dry and non-sticky. After folding them it takes only 10-15min to complete drying them. I made 9 pretty big taco shells. I think you could make around 12 smaller ones. It will be a sequel to this post with famous Allan's salsa recipe. Bon appétit! Asta

And you need just a few ingredients. It's not very easy to make them, but they are so worth it your time and frustration. Let me share with you my tips for making taco shells from flax seeds.

Flaxseed Taco Shells

  You'll need: 1 cup flaxseeds 1/4 cup sunflower seeds 1tsp cayenne pepper 1/4 red onion 1 clove garlic 1/2 red pepper salt and pepper to taste (about 1tsp each) Directions: 1. Mix flaxseeds with sunflower seeds and soak them overnight in 1.5 cups of water. Flax seeds will soak most of the water. The mixture will look like a pudding. 2. Put the mixture in the blender with the rest ingredients and blend everything to a dough. Set the dough in the fridge for half an hour 3. Now it's the most difficult part - to roll the dough and make taco shells. It'll be very sticky. I tried to roll it between two different baking papers. It works ok. Recently I took different approach. I cut the baking paper in the size of taco shells I wish to have, put some of the dough, cover it with plastic and flatten it with my fingers. This technique works best for me. 4. Preheat the oven to 160 degress. Set the flat shells on the baking tray and bake them in the oven for about 40min. They should become dry and not sticky anymore. Then it's time to make them look like real taco shells. It's pretty easy. Just fold them in half and bake for another 15min or so until they become totally dry.  Remove the paper and enjoy them with your favorite taco fillings. I always go for salsa, guacamole and minced meat. Yum! Note: the baking time will depend on taco shells size, thickness and your oven. Check once in a while to see if they became dry and non-sticky. After folding them it takes only 10-15min to complete drying them. I made 9 pretty big taco shells. I think you could make around 12 smaller ones. It will be a sequel to this post with ridiculously spicy Allan's salsa recipe. In a few days! Bon appétit! Asta
post_title: What happens during weekend, comes out on blog on Monday! ( +Flaxseed Tacos recipe)

post_content:
Happy Sunday! Waking up without alarm clock, walking around in pjs, drinking coffee and writing my blog. Lazy morning, no rush, perfect! One day a week has to be like this. Recently I was feeling bad, that I didn't have time to write my blog. I want to post more and share more, but during the week it is really difficult to find time for that. Writing a blog is a special occasion for me and I like spending time thinking about what to share about my life and my kitchen. I don't like rushing. But I need to dedicate more time during the week for writing. That's my promise to myself. Find time to blog a few times a week. Same as cooking, sharing my kitchen experiments makes me happy. Therefore I should allocate my time for things that make me happy, right? I had a lovely saturday. For the first time ever, I was hosting brunch! I like having people over for dinners, but had never ever invited anybody for breakfast or lunch. Last week we watched an episode of Cougar Town. They were having brunch.  I turned to Lucas and said: "We should host a  brunch!" We texted our friend whom we haven't seen for a long time and were planning to have him and his girlfriend over for dinner some time. They said yes, so the brunch was on! There were some restrictions for the brunch, because of the health issues. I had to make food following FodMap diet. I never heard of it until friday morning. After some research we had a list which foods are allowed. Basically, the diet avoids all the foods which upset your stomach or makes you gassy. That's my understanding of this diet

Here is the menu of my First Brunch:

 

Oven baked ramekin eggs with spinach and sun-dried tomatoes. Bacon Baked carrot cake oatmeal from the Green Kitchen Stories App Mimosas (can't have brunch without mimosa, right?) To round off the meal the had Green Detox drink.

Voila!

The recipe for the oven baked eggs is quite simple. You'll need 8 eggs, 200g spinach, 8 sun-dried tomatoes, some butter, salt and pepper, and 8 ramekins. Preheat the oven to 180 degrees. Blanch the spinach, chop the sun-dried tomatoes and butter the ramekins. Now it's time to assemble. Divide the spinach between the ramekins, top it with sun-dried tomatoes, egg, salt and pepper. Put it in the oven for about 10-12 minutes and enjoy! I think it's very easy and super good idea for the brunch when you need to make more eggs at the time. Oven and ramekins saves you. It looks fancy and tastes great! We loved it.

For the Green Detox drink you'll need: Half  cucumber Juice of 1 lemon 2 dates Bunch of mint Piece of ginger root 2 cups of water Blend everything and enjoy!   Baked carrot cake oatmeal recipe is on the Green Kitchen Stories App. If you don't have it yet, get it! So many yummy and healthy vegetarian recipes. Mimosas doesn't need a special recipe. Just mix some bubbly with orange juice (half -half) and enjoy! I'm off to have Dosa now! Sunday tradition. Have a wonderful day everybody! Be happy! Asta <3

post_content:
Happy Sunday! Waking up without alarm clock, walking around in pjs, drinking coffee and writing my blog. Lazy morning, no rush, perfect! One day a week has to be like this.

Recently I was feeling bad, that I didn't have time to write my blog. I want to post more and share more, but during the week it is really difficult to find time for that. Writing a blog is a special occasion for me and I like spending time thinking about what to share about my life and my kitchen. I don't like rushing. But I need to dedicate more time during the week for writing. That's my promise to myself. Find time to blog a few times a week. The same as cooking, sharing my kitchen experiments do make me happy. Therefore I should allocate my time for things that make me happy, right?

I had a lovely saturday. For the first time ever, I was hosting brunch! I like having people over for dinners, but had never ever invited anybody for breakfast or lunch. Last week we watched an episode of Cougar Town. They were having brunch.  I turned to Lucas and said: "I want to have brunch!" We texted our friend whom we haven't seen for a long time and were planning to have him and his girlfriend over for dinner some time. They said yes, so the brunch was on!

There were some restrictions for the brunch, because of the health issues. I had to make food following FodMap diet. I never heard of it until friday morning. After some research we had a list which foods are allowed. Basically, the diet avoids all the foods which upset your stomach or makes you gassy.

Here is the menu of my First Brunch:

Oven baked ramekin eggs with spinach and sun-dried tomatoes.
Bacon
Baked carrot cake oatmeal from the Green Kitchen Stories App
Mimosas (can't have brunch without mimosa, right?)
To round off the meal the had Green Detox drink.

Voila!

Blanch the spinach, chop the sun-dried tomatoes and butter the ramekins. Now it's time to assemble. Divide the spinach between the ramekins, top it with sun-dried tomatoes, egg, salt and pepper. Put it in the oven for about 10-12 minutes and enjoy! I think it's very easy and super good idea for the brunch when you need to make more eggs at the time. Oven and ramekins saves you. It looks fancy and tastes great! We loved it.

For the Green Detox drink you'll need: Half  cucumber Juice of 1 lemon 2 dates Bunch of mint Piece of ginger root 2 cups of water Blend everything and enjoy!   Baked carrot cake oatmeal recipe is on the Green Kitchen Stories App. If you don't have it yet, get it! So many yummy and healthy vegetarian recipes. Mimosas doesn't need a special recipe. Just mix some bubbly with orange juice (half -half) and enjoy! I'm off to have Dosa now! Sunday tradition. Have a wonderful day everybody! Be happy! Asta <3

Today I was thinking about my life in Norway, about friends, family and what does it mean to live in a foreign country. I moved to Norway more than four years ago. I believe that it was meant to be. My sister got a job offer in Oslo and I had an opportunity to come and finish my master studies at BI. It was easy to decide since my sister was going to move to the same city at the same time. I really wanted to study abroad and the timing seamed perfect. In the last four years happened a lot. I graduated, found my love, made new friends and finally figured out what I want to do in my life. I'm not sure how my life would have been if I stayed in Lithuania. But I am happy now and that is all what matters to me. Living abroad is not easy. The beginning was tough. Suddenly you are in the new place where you don't know anything, you don't know the culture, people, places, language. You have to invest your time and energy in learning, meeting new people and making new friends outside your comfort zone. The most difficult for me was to be far away from my very good friends, whom I new since my childhood. Suddenly I had to make new friends. I am always glad to meet new people from different cultures and countries. But I don't believe you can become friends over night. For me it takes time to open up and let people in to my heart. I believe in quality and not quantity of friends. Even if I miss my Lithuanian friends and think about them quite often, after four years in Norway I can say that I have met people here whom I call friends and believe that our connection will last forever. I feel like I belong here and I call Oslo my home now. The best thing about living in an international city as Oslo, is that you get to meet people from all over the world, you get to know their culture, traditions and food! It's not a surprise, I love food! And I would like to share with you some of the recipes I got from my international friends. Let's start with my friend Allan. He is a very nice guy from Texas, whom I was lucky to meet in Oslo. It was sad that he had to move back to the states, but I believe that I'll see him again. He shared with me his salsa recipe. I've been using it for the last half a year. Trust me, it's really good. Texicans know their tex-mex food. I haven't made any other salsa since. It's definitely a winner at our home. Though it is crazy spicy! If you are up for the challenge, here is the recipe:

Allan's salsa

You'll need: 400g of cherry tomatoes 5 fresh jalapenos 1 fresh habanero Juice of 1 lime 1 green pepper 1 red onion 3 cloves garlic 1 can of cherry tomatoes (400g) Handfull of fresh coriander 1 tsp of each: salt, pepper, cumin

Happy Hump Day! Hope you're having a wonderful week so far. Last night we went to the cinema to watch a new Wes Anderson movie - The Grand Budapest Hotel. I thought it was simply wonderful, funny, exciting, colorful and Brilliant! It is definitely one of the best movies I've seen so far. I literally enjoyed every single minute of it. If you haven't seen it yet, I highly reccomend!

If you haven't seen it yet, I highly recommend!   This movie reminded me of another excellent movies  by Wes Anderson - Moonrise Kingdom and Fantastic Mr. Fox. They are as well quirky, sweet, beautiful and funny. I want to watch them again! I think it's a good trio for a movie night with your friends. Charming, colorful movies which make you laugh and feel happy!

post_content:
"You see, there are still faint glimmers of civilization left in this barbaric slaughter house that was once known as humanity" - The Grand Budapest Hotel
Happy Hump Day! Hope you're having a wonderful week so far. Last night we went to the cinema to watch a new Wes Anderson movie - The Grand Budapest Hotel. I thought it was simply wonderful, funny, exciting, colorful and Brilliant! It is definitely one of the best movies I've seen so far. I literally enjoyed every single minute of it. If you haven't seen it yet, I highly recommend!   This movie reminded me of another excellent movies  by Wes Anderson - Moonrise Kingdom and Fantastic Mr. Fox. They are as well quirky, sweet, beautiful and funny. I want to watch them again! I think it's a good trio for a movie night with your friends. Charming, colorful movies which make you laugh and feel happy! If you're planning a movie night, you'll need some food, right? I suggest having tacos, because I like Mexican food.  I already posted my flax seed tacos and salsa recipes. And here goes my holy guacamole recipe. Simple, easy and super delicious! If you don't have time to make tacos, you can always use salsa and guacamole as yummy dips for chips or veggies for your movie night!

Holy Guacamoly

You'll need:

4 ripe avocados Half red onion 1 lime Handful of cherry tomatoes Bunch of fresh coriander 1 tsp of each: salt, cumin and cayenne pepper  Directions:  1. Finely chop onion, coriander and cherry tomatoes. 2. Mash avocados with the spices, half of onions and tomatoes. Use hand masher or blender. 3. And the rest of chopped onions and tomatoes, squeeze the lime juice and mix well. I always leave some onions and tomatoes non mashed. I like some crunchy bites in my guacamole. 4. Adjust salt, pepper and lime. Voila! Enjoy on the toast, with your tacos or as a dip. Sorry, no picture of the guacamole this time. The quality was not so good. But trust me, the taste is great! Will add the picture later, the next time I make it again. It'll be soon. I love guacamole. Have a wonderful the rest of the week  my lovelies! Don't forget to be Happy! Asta
post_title: Wes Anderson movie night (+ Holy Guacamoly recipe)

Finely chop onion, coriander and cherry tomatoes. 2. Mash avocados with the spices, half of onions and tomatoes. Use hand masher or blender. 3. "You see, there are still faint glimmers of civilization left in this barbaric slaughter house that was once known as humanity" - The Grand Budapest Hotel
Happy Hump Day! Hope you're having a wonderful week so far. Last night we went to the cinema to watch a new Wes Anderson movie - The Grand Budapest Hotel. I thought it was simply wonderful, funny, exciting, colorful and Brilliant! It is definitely one of the best movies I've seen so far. I literally enjoyed every single minute of it. If you haven't seen it yet, I highly recommend!   This movie reminded me of another excellent movies  by Wes Anderson - Moonrise Kingdom and Fantastic Mr. Fox. They are as well quirky, sweet, beautiful and funny. I want to watch them again! I think it's a good trio for a movie night with your friends. post_title: Wes Anderson movie night (+ Holy Guacamoly recipe)

post_content:
Friday, I'm in love!... With spring, life, love, food, music... Mayer Hawthorne iTunes radio channel is playing. Love his kind of music. Happy tunes, happy me. Didn't have to work today.  Yuppy! Love days for myself. In the morning had a session at the gym with a personal trainer. We worked on my upper body. OMG, my arms and back were shaking. He really pushed me hard. I am sure, I won't be able to lift anything tomorrow. But hopefully soon the hard work will pay off with bikini season body. After the hard workout, I treated myself with acai-blueberry smoothie. Blended together some frozen blueberries, acai powder, avocado, coconut water, oats and chia seeds. Topped with dried mulberries, coconut and cacao nibs. Voila! Really refreshing and rebooting. Love smoothies on the sunny days like today. Now it's time for Banana bread! For the third time this week. I am really  obsessed with it. Maybe because we had so many eggs and bananas at home. I decided to make something from them. So, I baked banana bread and me and boyfriend loved it! First try was with pomegranate seeds and pistachios. Really good. Second time I used cranberries. It was good, but not great. My last choice was pomegranate and walnuts. Perfection! I am sure you can make with something else and it'll be great. Just choose whatever you like. I love pomegranate. My tip to open it quickly. Cut pomegranate in half. Put it in the bowl of cold water. Wait ten minutes. It'll be pretty easy to remove the seeds after that. Trust me. Here goes my banana bread recipe:

Banana Bread Love

(gluten, dairy & sugar free)

You'll need: 4 ripe bananas 4 eggs 8 pitted dates 1/4 cup coconut oil 1/2 coconut flour 1Tbsp baking powder 1tsp cinnamon 1/2tsp nutmeg seeds from 1 pomegranate handful of walnuts   Directions: 1. Preheat the oven to 180 degrees. Grease the bread baking tray with some coconut oil, half teaspoon. 2. Blend bananas, egg, coconut oil and dates. 3. Add coconut flour, cinnamon, baking powder and nutmeg. Mix in everything by hand just to combine. 4. Add walnuts and pomegranate seeds. Mix them in. 5. Pour in the bread baking tray. Put in the oven and bake for about 45min. Start checking after half an hour. The toothpick inserted in the bread should come out clean. Voila! Tastes great on its own or with some peanut butter or ice cream on top. Yum! I am off to IKEA now. Thinking about redecorating our kitchen. Since I spend so much time in it. Will see what IKEA has to offer. Have a wonderful weekend everybody! Asta <3
